info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 33.

(1, 1).clue: Shagreen, the dried skin of this meat eater, was once used as sandpaper

(3, 1).clue: One of these with a carrot nose was the mascot of the 1976 Winter Games in Innsbruck

(4, 1).clue: In the 1840s a potato famine killed close to 1 million in this country

(5, 1).clue: Horace Mann began his career as "The Father of American Public Education" in the 1830s in this "Bay State"

(6, 1).clue: A plant, Apium graveolens, of the parsley family

(1, 2).clue: Unlike most sea animals, in the sea horse this pair of sense organs can move independently of one another

(3, 2).clue: Decked out in a red, white & blue top hat, an eagle named this was the mascot of the 1984 Los Angeles games

(4, 2).clue: Science class: with a little wire & strips of copper & zinc, you can turn lemons or potatoes into these

(5, 2).clue: Mann depended on an itinerant teacher to learn Latin, required for entry to this Rhode Island Ivy League school

(6, 2).clue: Credit card ad:Cost of books to help study for tournament, $412... beating Ken Jennings, this 9-letter word

(1, 3).clue: In 1957 this undersea explorer became director of Monaco's Oceanographic Museum

(3, 3).clue: The mascots for the 2004 Summer Games were a brother & sister named Phevos & this, like the Greek goddess

(4, 3).clue: Made of hollow metal, earthenware or plastic, this musical instrument is also called a "sweet potato"

(5, 3).clue: Mann said, "Be ashamed to die until you have won some victory for" this; oh, the this!

(6, 3).clue: This New World cat can be 4 feet long, including the tail

(1, 4).clue: The largest crustacean is a Japanese species of this; it can measure 12 feet between its claws

(3, 4).clue: Hidy & Howdy, polar bears with cowboy hats, were the mascots of the 1988 Winter Games in this city

(4, 4).clue: Famous for another spuddy image, he painted the potato-peeling peasant seen here

(5, 4).clue: Mann: "Seek not greatness but seek" this "and you will find both"; you might get justice & the American way, too

(6, 4).clue: Full title of the Minister of Finance in the British government

(1, 5).clue: (Jeff Probst, host of Survivor, delivers the clue from Palau.)  This nearly extinct sea cow is found in the coastal waters of Palau, & even here, it is threatened by poaching

(3, 5).clue: The mascots for the Sydney games were Syd the platypus, Olly the kookaburra, and Millie, this spiny anteater

(4, 5).clue: Most of this state's potatoes are produced in Aroostook County

(5, 5).clue: In 1848 Mann again "donned" this political party in winning a second term in Congress

(6, 5).clue: The University of this seaport city on the Mediterranean was founded in 1450

(1, 1).clue: On Dec. 30, 2002 this billionaire mayor signed a law banning smoking in most working-class bars

(3, 1).clue: In September 1992, noted humanitarian Audrey Hepburn visited this famine-stricken African country

(5, 1).clue: Little Wolfie played piano duets sitting on the lap of J.C., "the English" member of this musical family

(6, 1).clue: CBers & C.W. McCall use it to mean "okay"

(1, 2).clue: Mayor Dinkins fought to divest the city of funds invested in companies that did business with this country

(3, 2).clue: The Nevsky Cathedral seen here is a landmark in this Eastern European capital city

(4, 2).clue: Silver-107 & silver-109 are 2 naturally occurring these of silver

(5, 2).clue: Lorenzo Da Ponte simultaneously wrote librettos for "Don Giovanni" & this Mozart rival's "Tarare"

(6, 2).clue: New York Central Railroad's flagship train, it ran from Chicago to New York City from 1902 to 1967

(1, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Umbertos in New York City.) As part of a civil lawsuit, in 1987, the Feds took over Umbertos at the request of this U.S. attorney and future mayor, but couldn't make a go of it

(3, 3).clue: Guadalcanal is part of this nation of islands east of New Guinea

(4, 3).clue: Light changes colorless silver ions into black silver atoms, leading to this technology in the 1830s

(5, 3).clue: Michael Puchberg, a fellow member of this secret society depicted in "The Magic Flute", was a soft touch for loans

(6, 3).clue: These were posted October 31, 1517; the Archbishop of Mainz got a copy

(1, 4).clue: This flamboyant pol has the distinction of being the only mayor to later host "The People's Court"

(3, 4).clue: The Bear Flag Republic was proclaimed in this California city now known as a wine center

(4, 4).clue: Silver is the best metal conductor of these 2 things

(5, 4).clue: In scores for this type of work for orchestra & soloist, Mozart said horn player Ignaz Leutgeb was an ass, ox & fool

(6, 4).clue: This 1844 rallying cry referred to the northern boundary of the Oregon Territory

(1, 5).clue: Mayor George McClellan was subjected to scathing newspaper attacks when running against this mogul

(3, 5).clue: One of the possible sites for Camelot is said to have been South Cadbury in this historic English county

(4, 5).clue: Silver is second only to gold in ductility & this, the ability to be hammered into thin sheets

(5, 5).clue: Mozart wrote a lovely motet for Venanzio Rauzzini, one of these specially treated singers

(6, 5).clue: The heroes in the title of this Aeschylus tragedy include Polyneices, Tydeus & Capaneus

(0, 0).clue: A chemist in the 1920s coined this term after finding lavender oil not only hid the odor of his burnt hand but also healed it
